is it good practice to have a bunch of try catch blocks side by side?

message.div: i just answered a question on SO
try catch blocks are defensive coding
which is usually good but there are two problems with them
one is that, from what I understand, they're expensive
the other is that if you catch an error and don't do anything about it — you're shooting yourself in the foot
and by "don't do anything about it" i mean if you can't discover the error during runtime if it happens

div.span: yeah, i'm not actually recovering from any errors, just logging them

message.div: looks like it doesn't matter too much
the second answer is an op-ed
readability — i think try-catch blocks are pretty explicit
try this, catch that, finally do x
"try this, catch err and do that, finally run x"
inappropriate — depends on how you use it

is legit — I don't have an opinion on the logging. one person says: "In my opinion, logging every exception is a good idea, as long as you do it high up in the call stack and add a "throw;" statement right after."
there are some good points in it
basically the comments in the first answer are all great
